qas.question: Which seabird has the longest-distance migration?
Which bird sees more daylight than any other during migration?
How long did one Arctic tern take to migrate?
How far did the Arctic tern chick travel?

context: Seabird migration is similar in pattern to those of the waders and waterfowl. Some, such as the black guillemot Cepphus grylle and some gulls, are quite sedentary; others, such as most terns and auks breeding in the temperate northern hemisphere, move varying distances south in the northern winter. <a0_0><a1_0>The Arctic tern<a1_0/><a0_0/> Sterna paradisaea has the longest-distance migration of any bird, and sees more daylight than any other, moving from its Arctic breeding grounds to the Antarctic non-breeding areas. One Arctic tern, ringed (banded) as a chick on the Farne Islands off the British east coast, reached Melbourne, Australia in just <a2_0>three months<a2_0/> from fledging, a sea journey of over <a3_0>22,000 km<a3_0/> (14,000 mi). Many tubenosed birds breed in <a4_0>the southern hemisphere<a4_0/> and migrate north in the southern winter.
